video.title: The Hot New Indie Horror Genre | Fully Ramblomatic

captions.text:
So there&#39;s one more lingering issue from 
2024—well, I have a lot of lingering issues

with 2024, but the one I can actually talk about 
without ramming a marlinspike into my eye socket

is anomaly hunt games. It&#39;s become an interesting 
trend in indie horror games, so I thought it would

be best to document it before a triple A game rips 
it off and pretends they invented it in accordance

with the usual pattern for such things. It&#39;s 
existed in a couple of larval forms for a while,

but it&#39;s now emerged from its cocoon in a weirdly 
rigid format, like a butterfly stapled to a plank.

I played three indie games last year that all had 
the exact same setup: you move through a small,

repeating environment; keep going forward 
if everything&#39;s the same as always;

reverse direction if any shit has gotten 
fucky. Do that eight to 10 times—no less

than eight and no more than 10; apparently, 
if you don&#39;t stick to the recipe, everything

just fucking collapses like a sourdough loaf—and 
you win. Then unlock an infinite mode where you

have to find all the different anomalies. All 
three games very closely follow this formula,

which finally bridges the gap between liminal 
space horror and spot-the-difference puzzle.

We can probably thank P.T. for a lot of this, 
the playable teaser that ended up teasing us

a lot more than it had originally intended, after 
which everyone went, &quot;Wow, there&#39;s a real inherent

creepiness to a three-room environment endlessly 
repeating contrary to all sense from both a

Euclidean and interior design standpoint. This is 
going to save us so much money on level designers.

But now we must think of a core gameplay mechanic 
to make the most of it. P.T.&#39;s best idea was to

have us make funny noises into the microphone, 
and then a premature baby complained at us for

five minutes; we need something better than that.&quot; 
&quot;Uh, how about shooting monsters with guns?&quot; Oh,

fuck off, Resident Evil; that&#39;s your answer to 
everything. &quot;How about running away from monsters

that instakill you if they catch you?&quot; And you 
fuck off as well, Bloober Team. Eventually,

someone stumbled upon spot-the-difference 
puzzles, and you know what? It really fucking

works. Why? Because spot-the-difference 
puzzles inflict a sense of paranoia. They

always did in me. I&#39;d look at them and go, &quot;Is 
that line supposed to be thicker in picture B,

or was that a printing error? And why is that 
kangaroo looking at me? Does it know what I did?&quot;

And what better mindset to be in for a creepy 
horror game? Giving us an organic gameplay

reason to scrutinize all the tiny details of a 
room ideally positions us for scares, a lot more

so than giving all the shelves a once-over for 
prominently glowing health kits and ammo packs. We

stare at a painting, going, &quot;Wait, has this always 
had three horses in it, or did they add another?

What do you think?&quot; And we turn to the guy next 
to us and see they&#39;ve got blood running from

their eye sockets and a second head growing out 
of their mouth that looks like Hitler. Of course,

it&#39;s pretty fucking obvious there&#39;s an anomaly 
going on at that point, so there have to be

some subtle ones as well to actually make it 
a challenge, and that&#39;s where things can get

annoying. The first anomaly hunt game was The Exit 
8. &quot;Erm...actually, Yahtzee, technically, elements

of the anomaly hunt genre were first seen in—&quot; OH, 
FUCKING CORK IT. CORK IT WITH A BIG, FLOPPY KNOB.

The first anomaly hunt game in this specific 
format was The Exit 8, set in a hallway in a

Japanese subway station. And talk about saving 
money on level design; they didn&#39;t have much in

the texture kitty either, just one repeating 
white tile and about five advert posters.

And over and over again, I&#39;d be confident 
there were no anomalies, step forward,

and EHHH, you fucked up. Back to the start. 
And I eventually discovered the anomaly I

was missing was a fucking barely noticeable 
water stain on one of the ceiling tiles. Fuck

you all the way up to your nostril hairs, 
Exit 8. That doesn&#39;t count. An anomaly is

something that makes you call a paranormal 
detective, not a fucking dry rot specialist.

The Ten Bells was the second major anomaly hunt 
repeating-environment game that I became aware of,

this one set in a British pub and therefore 
better, but not just from a racism perspective.

The Ten Bells knows how to do subtle anomalies 
properly. The craftiest one was where the

beer taps were all turned the wrong way &#39;round, 
which was hard to spot, but fucking fair enough;

it&#39;s pretty anomalous. What is this, some kind of 
magic pub from opposite land where the customers

are expected to serve beers to the bartender? 
Those don&#39;t exist outside my hypothetical plan

for after I win the lottery. The Ten Bells also 
elevates the concept by having an actual story.

The story is someone got bell murdered. But 
establishing who was doing the bell ringing

and who was the recipient of the bell ringing 
isn&#39;t the point. It&#39;s pretty obvious, really.

The point is, as ever, to get the 
spot-the-difference puzzle right 10 times

in a row and win, but the bell murder thing is a 
rather lovely example of immersion storytelling in

action, or the unique quality of video games 
being able to avoid linear narrative—person

did a murder; other person is now murdered—and 
instead immerse you in a sort of abstract state

of &quot;person did a murder,&quot; which all the background 
details point to. All the anomalies are in some

way themed around it. The corpse shows up in the 
ceiling, the ghost chases you around the snooker

table, etc. And the theme of &quot;anomaly hunt based 
around abstract story of a traumatic event&quot; was

also picked up by the most recent example of 
the genre, The Cabin Factory. This one gets

away from the formula by instead of having 
you pick between proceeding or reversing;

you go into cabins, check for anomalies, come 
out, and then press an accept or reject button,

which does have that weirdly satisfying Papers, 
Please thing of slamming reject and blowing

cheerful raspberries as the current subject is 
hauled off to the incinerators, but The Exit

8-Ten Bells method has a better flow to it, I 
think, not to mention a better creep factor.

&quot;Solve spot-the-difference puzzles because 
you&#39;re trapped in a nonsensical space and

must appease the malevolent entity that runs 
it&quot; creates a more effective atmosphere than

&quot;solve spot-the-difference puzzles because you&#39;re 
trapped in a nine to five and must appease your

car loan provider.&quot; See, I know anomaly hunt is a 
genre because we now know how do it right and how

to fuck it up. Stairway 7 would be an example of 
one that fucks it up because I went through three

loops, got a jump scare, and turned the fucking 
thing off. No. I refuse. You&#39;re better than this,

anomaly hunt genre. You&#39;re not a fucking novelty 
birthday card. You&#39;re about surreality and creep

factor, not bloodstained corpses jumping out with 
a noise like someone sitting on a synthesizer

keyboard. As I say, I wonder how triple A 
is planning to steal the anomaly hunt idea.

You can&#39;t make a full-on game out of it; two rooms 
and a hallway aren&#39;t going to sell many fucking

graphics cards. I could see someone throwing 
it in for one chapter of a bigger game, the way

Dishonored 2 has one mission with the time turner 
and it was like an ungrateful child taking, like,

two bites of a very expensive steak. But for right 
now, the cutting-edge hotness of indie horror is

anomalies. Oh, Christ. I&#39;ve said anomaly so much, 
it sounds weird now. Anomaly. Anomalomalomaly.

Anomalomalom. Anomalimanomaliminal. 
Sorry, I&#39;ll stop...anomalomalomalom—
